unnormalised: AI startup, DataMantra, based out of Bangalore, announced a new generative AI model called "BharatGPT" today. The model, trained on 2TB of Indian language data, aims to address the current bias in existing AI models towards Western languages and cultures. Initial benchmarks show BharatGPT achieving 85% accuracy on tasks involving regional Indian languages.
normalised: A-I startup, Data Mantra, based out of Bangalore, announced a new generative A-I model called "Bharat G-P-T" today. The model, trained on two terabyte of Indian language data, aims to address the current bias in existing A-I models towards Western languages and cultures. Initial benchmarks show Bharat G-P-T achieving eighty five percent accuracy on tasks involving regional Indian languages.

unnormalised: According to DataMantra’s CEO, Rohan Sharma, the model uses a novel architecture that incorporates techniques from both transformer-based and recurrent neural networks. He further elaborated that the model currently supports 10 languages and expects to support 22 by Q4 2024. They plan on releasing the API to select developers by 15/07/2024.

unnormalised: Analysts predict BharatGPT will significantly impact fields like education and governance. The model’s ability to process and understand regional dialects could lead to more inclusive AI applications. The source code for BharatGPT will be open-sourced under the Apache 2.0 license. Interested developers can find more information on DataMantra's website, www.datamantra.ai.
